channel.title: Resources on p5.fab
channel.description: Recent content in Resources on p5.fab

item.title: A Gentle Introduction to Creative Coding with p5.js
item.description: A Gentle Introduction to Creative Coding with p5.js # This page provides a brief introduction to some key concepts for creative coding with p5.js. It is by no means exhaustive, but provides helpful background information for newcomers to dicreative code. If you’re already familiar with computer-controlled machines but want to learn a bit about digital fabrication, check out the digital fabrication intro, or if you want to learn how to make things with p5.

item.title: A Gentle Introduction to Digital Fabrication
item.description: A Gentle Introduction to Digital Fabrication # This page provides a brief introduction to some key concepts in digital fabrication. It is by no means exhaustive, but provides helpful background information for newcomers to digital fabrication machines. If you’re already familiar with computer-controlled machines but want to learn a bit about creative coding, check out the creative coding intro, or if you want to learn how to make things with p5.

item.title: Cube Tutorial
item.description: Printing a Cube # Check out the cube example in the online editor. It shows how to stack extrusions up to make a simple, hollow cube. If you’re comfortable with this, check out the interactive cube tutorial to see how to use a MIDI controller to change printing parameters.

item.title: Etch A Sketch
item.description: Etch A Sketch # Instead of modifying toolpaths design asynchronously, we can try sending commands continuously to the machine. This tutorial will talk through a simple ’etch a sketch’ example using a MIDI controller. Step 0: Gather Materials # You’ll need: A 3D printer + filament a USB cable to connect your computer to your printer A MIDI controller + USB cable Step 1: Define MIDI inputs # Go to the online editor and open the ’etch-a-sketch’ example.

item.title: Getting Started Tutorial
item.description: Getting Started # I recommend using the online editor to get started. It lets you to write code, start/stop prints, connect to MIDI devices, and connect to a camera in one place. Step 0: Gather materials # You’ll need: A 3D printer + filament Google Chrome browser a USB cable to connect your computer to your printer Step 1: The online editor # Using Chrome, open the online editor. (We have to use Chrome because it’s the only browser that supports WebSerial).

item.title: Interactive Cube
item.description: Interactive Cube # We can use a MIDI controller to interactively edit commands as they’re being sent to the machine. This tutorial will walk through and example to change the print speed, extrusion, and deposition height of a simple cube. Step 0: Gather Materials # You’ll need: A 3D printer + filament a USB cable to connect your computer to your printer A MIDI controller + USB cable Step 1: Connect a MIDI controller # Go to the online editor and open the ‘interactive cube’ example.

item.title: Line Vase Tutorial
item.description: Line Vase Tutorial # Stay tuned! For now, check out the line vase example on the online editor.

item.title: Non-Planar Printing Tutorial
item.description: Non-Planar Printing # Check out the non-planar example in the online editor. It shows how to move out of the x-y plane while printing. If you’re comfortable with this, see the interactive cube tutorial to see how to use a MIDI controller to change printing parameters.

item.title: p5.fab Primer
item.description: p5.fab Primer # This page provides an introduction to using p5.fab. If you’re new to digital fabrication and/or creative code and want some more context for the information presented here, check out the digital fabrication and creative coding introductions. Anatomy of a p5.fab Sketch # p5.fab adds to the default setup() and draw() functions a fabDraw() function. fabDraw() is run once, immediately after setup and before the first draw loop, and is where any code which generates toolpath should go!
